title: Buoyant force raft crane and block

content.question: At the instant shown in the figure, a raft of density <math alttext="rho sub raft" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub></math> is floating at rest in water of density <math alttext="rho sub water" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>water</mtext></msub></math>, where <math alttext="rho sub water is greater than rho sub raft" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>water</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub></math>. A crane of negligible mass attached to the raft holds a solid block of density <math alttext="rho sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, where <math alttext="rho sub block is greater than rho sub water" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>water</mtext></msub></math>, and the block is partially submerged in the water. The cross-sectional area of the block parallel to the surface of the water is much smaller than that of the raft. The crane then lowers the block a distance <math alttext="d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math> further into the water and the raft-block system again comes to rest. After the crane lowers the block a distance <math alttext="d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, the raft remains horizontal and has risen by an average distance <math alttext="d sub raft" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly compares <math alttext="d sub raft" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub></math> to <math alttext="d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="d sub raft is less than d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, because the raft has a greater cross-sectional area than the block.

<math alttext="d sub raft is less than d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, because the density of the raft is less than that of the block.

<math alttext="d sub raft equals d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, because the buoyant force on the raft is equal to that on the block.

<math alttext="d sub raft equals d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, because the total volume of water displaced by the raft-block system is the same before and after the block is lowered.

content.answer: <math alttext="d sub raft is less than d sub block" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>raft</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>block</mtext></msub></math>, because the raft has a greater cross-sectional area than the block.
